results.title: Evaluating your discussion
results.creator_credit: Educational Research and Development and Teachers Education Program and Far West Laboratory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
Designed to help high school students with evaluating and discussing controversial issues. The topics in this film are: George Orwell’s “1984”; Students Appeal Board; and Police reactions - role reversal.

results.title: Understanding different points of view
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall and Far West Laboratory for Educational Research and Development
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”
Explains that to provide good discussion and to understand other points of view the participants should: give reasons, ask for reasons and ask for clarification; while the Moderator should: ask for reasons, state areas of agreement and disagreement and ask for temporary agreement.

results.title: The Importance of listening
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall, Educational Research and Development and Teacher Education and Far West Laboratory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
If a discussion is to be useful it is essential to listen. The onus to keep the discussion going is on both the moderator and the participants. The moderator should: Summarise ideas and restore issues. The participants should: Listen to the other person’s ideas, acknowledge others’ ideas, question relevance. The case represented in this film is a discussion between black and white high school students and a white policeman concerning a fatal police shooting of a black man. The film uses this topic to illustrate skills of keeping a discussion on track (as a mediator) and relating participants’ comments and questions to each other.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall, Educational Research and Development and Teacher Education and Far West Laboratory

results.title: Creating an open discussion
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall and Far West Laboratory for Educational Research and Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
By providing topics for discussion teachers acting as moderators in separate classrooms show how a discussion can be productively carried out. The film clearly shows the jobs of both the moderator and the participants. Shows how to develop an open (non-threatening) situation in which meaningful discussions can take place.

results.title: How do children think?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
Discusses Piaget’s research and theories of the main periods of development in children. To advance beyond the stage of primitive concrete operations, children need opportunities for the kind of work they do in primary schools, based on activity, discussion, and the growth of social relationships.

results.title: Movement in time and space
results.creator_credit: Eileen Molony and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
The outside world consists of experiences rather than objects, to the young child. Socialisation of the school child takes place only after a series of explorations and discoveries about being a person. Music, movement, and drama once considered recreational functions, are now regarded as ways of exploring space, time and personality.

results.title: Finding out
results.creator_credit: George Luger, Eileen Molony and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
Educational research into the mental processes of young children has confirmed the value of growing emphasis on activity, experience and exploration for primary school children. Designed primarily for parents and students training to be teachers.

results.title: Maths is a monster
results.creator_credit: Eileen Molony and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
Considers the effect the research of Jean Piaget has had on the teaching of mathematics. Primary school children think in concrete terms so the lessons of modern maths are drawn from life inside and outside school. Shows children of different abilities tackling various kinds of mathematical work, discovering relations between concepts and developing abstract thinking abilities.

results.title: The Changeover
results.creator_credit: Eileen Molony and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
As there is growing emphasis in education on what a child does rather than what the teacher says, a gradual change in teaching methods and class management has taken place. Discusses new concepts in teaching, teacher training, classroom organisation and the attitude of the teacher to the children. Suitable for teacher training.
